Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/bricerising/git/brice@github/specify-poker/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)

- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.

  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:

  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Planning CSS and UI enhancements**

Im mapping out how to add styling by creating a global CSS file linked through index.html and updating components with classNames for layout and visual polish. Im also thinking about adding simple SVG art elements like a PokerArt component for a nicer look without external libraries, plus fonts with fallback options given network restraints. To keep things lively, Ill add CSS animations and background gradients with patterns, all while restructuring the app shell to improve navigation and content presentation. This involves blending style additions and functional upgrades thoughtfully.

summary.text:

To keep things lively, Ill add CSS animations and background gradients with patterns, all while restructuring the app shell to improve navigation and content presentation. This involves blending style additions and functional upgrades thoughtfully.

**Designing consistent UI layout and styles**

Im planning a full UI overhaul with styled components, CSS variables, and a clear layout including header, nav, lobby, and table pages. Ill create reusable components like PokerArt and card styles, organize forms with field groups, add intuitive labels and placeholders, and build responsive grids for tables and seats. Im focusing on clean structure and user-friendly visuals, using CSS for backgrounds, animations, and typography to deliver a cohesive poker app experience.

+import React from "react";
+
+interface PokerArtProps {
+  variant?: "hero" | "table";
+}
+
+export function PokerArt({ variant = "hero" }: PokerArtProps) {
+  const size = variant === "hero" ? 280 : 220;
+  return (
+    <svg
+      className={`poker-art poker-art-${variant}`}
+      width={size}
+      height={size}
+      viewBox="0 0 320 260"
+      role="img"
+      aria-hidden="true"
+    >
+      <defs>
+        <linearGradient id="card-shine" x1="0" y1="0" x2="1" y2="1">
+          <stop offset="0%" stopColor="var(--card)" />
+          <stop offset="100%" stopColor="var(--card-soft)" />
+        </linearGradient>
+      </defs>
+      <rect x="22" y="36" width="118" height="168" rx="14" fill="url(#card-shine)" />
+      <rect x="36" y="52" width="90" height="4" rx="2" fill="var(--card-ink)" opacity="0.3" />
+      <rect x="36" y="64" width="70" height="4" rx="2" fill="var(--card-ink)" opacity="0.2" />
+      <rect x="160" y="18" width="118" height="168" rx="14" fill="url(#card-shine)" />
+      <rect x="176" y="34" width="84" height="4" rx="2" fill="var(--card-ink)" opacity="0.3" />
+      <rect x="176" y="46" width="54" height="4" rx="2" fill="var(--card-ink)" opacity="0.2" />
+      <circle cx="72" cy="186" r="44" fill="var(--chip-outer)" />

+      <circle cx="238" cy="190" r="48" fill="var(--chip-outer)" />
+      <circle cx="238" cy="190" r="35" fill="var(--chip-inner)" />

+      <path

payload.message:
Reworked the UI to feel more human and guided, with a new visual shell, clearer hierarchy, and inline poker art to anchor each screen. The layout now emphasizes what to do next (join/create, act, chat) and uses card-style panels plus motion for clarity.

Details:
- Added a global design system and background treatment in `apps/ui/public/styles.css`, plus font and stylesheet links in `apps/ui/public/index.html`.
- Built reusable poker illustration `apps/ui/src/components/PokerArt.tsx` and surfaced it on the login screen, lobby, and table view.
- Refactored UI structure and copy in `apps/ui/src/main.tsx` and page components to make navigation, actions, and status more intuitive (`apps/ui/src/pages/LobbyPage.tsx`, `apps/ui/src/pages/TablePage.tsx`, `apps/ui/src/pages/ProfilePage.tsx`, `apps/ui/src/pages/FriendsPage.tsx`).
- Styled forms and interaction panels for clarity and consistency in `apps/ui/src/components/CreateTableForm.tsx`, `apps/ui/src/components/ActionBar.tsx`, `apps/ui/src/components/ChatPanel.tsx`, `apps/ui/src/components/ModerationMenu.tsx`, and `apps/ui/src/components/ProfileForm.tsx`.

Next steps:
1) Run the UI locally: `npm run start -w @specify-poker/ui`
2) If you want tweaks to tone or visual direction, tell me which screen feels off and Ill iterate.

payload.message:
I found why its not showing: Grafana is only mounting `infra/grafana` into `/etc/grafana/provisioning`, so your dashboard JSON never lands in the path Grafana watches. I wired the mounts and dashboard path so the JSON is discoverable.

Changes:
- `docker-compose.yml` now mounts `infra/grafana/provisioning` to `/etc/grafana/provisioning` and `infra/grafana/dashboards` to `/etc/grafana/dashboards`.
- `infra/grafana/provisioning/dashboards/dashboards.yaml` now points to `/etc/grafana/dashboards`.

Next steps:
1) `docker compose up -d grafana`
2) In Grafana, look under Dashboards  Browse  poker-dashboards.

If it still doesnt appear, tell me your Grafana container logs and Ill trace further.

payload.message:
Chat now carries and renders the player nickname instead of the raw UUID.

What I changed:
- Server emits `nickname` with each chat message in `apps/api/src/ws/chatHub.ts`.
- UI prefers `nickname` and falls back to `userId` in `apps/ui/src/components/ChatPanel.tsx`.

If you want the nickname to update live when someone edits their profile, I can also wire a refresh or a lookup on the client side.

content.text:
Chat now carries and renders the player nickname instead of the raw UUID.

What I changed:
- Server emits `nickname` with each chat message in `apps/api/src/ws/chatHub.ts`.
- UI prefers `nickname` and falls back to `userId` in `apps/ui/src/components/ChatPanel.tsx`.

If you want the nickname to update live when someone edits their profile, I can also wire a refresh or a lookup on the client side.
Seats should become unselectable when someone is in them

**Extending TableSummary with seat occupancy**

I'm planning to add an `occupiedSeatIds` field to the TableSummary type by extracting seat occupancy from the current table state. This involves updating the API, registry summary sync, and the UI lobby page to reflect which seats are taken by disabling their buttons and labeling them as "Taken." I'll carefully adjust types and consider tests that might be sensitive to the shape changes, aiming for a straightforward patch to include this new occupancy info.

payload.message:
Seats are now disabled in the lobby when theyre already occupied. I added occupied seat IDs to the table summary, kept it in sync on the API side, and used that list to disable the Join Seat buttons.

Changes:
- Added `occupiedSeatIds` to the table summary model in `apps/api/src/services/tableTypes.ts` and `apps/ui/src/state/tableStore.ts`.
- Populated `occupiedSeatIds` during summary sync in `apps/api/src/services/tableService.ts`.
- Disabled seat buttons based on `occupiedSeatIds` in `apps/ui/src/pages/LobbyPage.tsx`.

If you want, I can also visually style disabled seats more clearly (e.g., greyed out with a Taken pill).

payload.text:
**Designing nickname integration in table state**

I'm working out how to add nicknames to table seats for UI display without disrupting engine logic. I'll create an async view model that enriches the existing TableState with nicknames fetched from profiles on each broadcast. This involves extending types with optional nickname fields, adjusting async methods to await this enrichment, and updating UI types to use nicknames where availablewhile keeping engine types mostly untouched. I'll carefully update all places that send or handle table state to include this enriched view for consistent display.

summary.text:
**Designing nickname integration in table state**

I'm working out how to add nicknames to table seats for UI display without disrupting engine logic. I'll create an async view model that enriches the existing TableState with nicknames fetched from profiles on each broadcast. This involves extending types with optional nickname fields, adjusting async methods to await this enrichment, and updating UI types to use nicknames where availablewhile keeping engine types mostly untouched. I'll carefully update all places that send or handle table state to include this enriched view for consistent display.

**Implementing nickname support for table seats**

I'll add a nickname field to each TableSeat by fetching user profiles, updating tableHub to include these nicknames in table state payloads, and adjusting UI types and components like TablePage and ModerationMenu to display nicknames gracefully alongside user IDs or fallback labels. I'll ensure data copying to avoid mutations and update call sites broadcasting table state accordingly.

payload.text:
**Verifying and guarding TableSeat payload usage**

I'm double-checking where the TableSeat-related payload is used across various handlers to ensure we handle the possibility of null returns safely. I see potential for TypeScript errors since buildTableStatePayload can return null, so I plan to add explicit non-null checks before using the payload in functions like broadcastTableState, joinSeat, leaveSeat, and others, making sure to prevent runtime issues and satisfy TypeScript's type system.

payload.message:
Seat labels now use player nicknames instead of UUIDs.

What changed:
- Added nickname enrichment to table state snapshots/patches in `apps/api/src/ws/tableHub.ts` by looking up each seated users profile on broadcast.
- Updated UI seat rendering to prefer `nickname` in `apps/ui/src/pages/TablePage.tsx` and `apps/ui/src/components/ModerationMenu.tsx`.
- Extended UI seat type in `apps/ui/src/state/tableStore.ts` to include `nickname`.

Next steps:
1) Restart the API server so the websocket payload includes nicknames.
2) Refresh the UI and rejoin a table.

content.text:
Seat labels now use player nicknames instead of UUIDs.

What changed:
- Added nickname enrichment to table state snapshots/patches in `apps/api/src/ws/tableHub.ts` by looking up each seated users profile on broadcast.
- Updated UI seat rendering to prefer `nickname` in `apps/ui/src/pages/TablePage.tsx` and `apps/ui/src/components/ModerationMenu.tsx`.
- Extended UI seat type in `apps/ui/src/state/tableStore.ts` to include `nickname`.

Next steps:
1) Restart the API server so the websocket payload includes nicknames.
2) Refresh the UI and rejoin a table.
